title: CTRL0000916113 - Transcribed Interview of Alexander Cannon, (Aug. 18, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 12:59 p.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
SENIOR COUNSELOR TO THE VICE CHAIR
This is the transcribed interview of Alex
Cannon, conducted by the House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
on the United States Capitol, pursuant to House Resolution 503.
At this time, I'm going to ask the witness to please state your full name for the
And, Mr. Cannon, this will be a staff-led interview, though
Members may choose to ask questions.
At this time, I do not see any members present.
senior investigative counsel; to my right,
we are joined b y - v i a the Webex who is senior counsel to the vice chair.
I'm an investigative counsel with the
With me from the select committee is
At this time, I'd ask your counsel to identify himself for the record and any lawyers
Daniel Benson, Kasowitz Benson Torres, representing Mr. Cannon,
and joining me is Jonathan Gonzales of our firm and Jacob Benson of our firm.
Now, Mr. Cannon, you are voluntarily here for
official reporter transcribing the record of this interview.
The ground rules for this interview are, first, there's an
The proceeding is also audio and video recorded, and we ask that you do not
audio or video record the proceeding.
Please wait until each question is complete before you begin to response, and
we'll do our best to wait until your response is complete before we ask the next question.
The reporter cannot note nonverbal responses, such as shaking or nodding your
So it's important that you respond to each question with an audible, verbal
Please give complete answers to the best of your recollection, and if the answer is
If you don't know an answer, please just say so.
We're happy to take any breaks for you, whether comfort breaks, to speak with
Just let us know, we're happy to accommodate.
Now before we begin, do you have any questions?
Mr. Cannon, seeing that we had a prior transcribed interview with
you, we're not going to go over some of the biographical and educational information
that you stated the first time we met with you.
In preparation for this interview, did you collect documents that were responsive
Can you describe that process for us?
I contacted our e-discovery vendor, asked them to bring down data that
would've been responsive to the request.
that was responsive to your request.
I reviewed the data and produced the data
And who is that e-discovery vendor?
That's 2M Document Management -- Imaging and Management.
Going forward, we'll just refer to them as 2M.
And we see from -- and without getting into conversations you had with your
lawyer, in the documents you produced, there are a variety of redactions in those
Did you review all those redactions before the production was made to us?
So it's fair to say that, to the best of your ability, you believe all
those redactions and the related substance as indicated on the face of redactions are
So today, Mr. Cannon, we're going to speak a bit about -- just
giving you a roadmap, because we're going to try to make this a pretty relatively quick
interview and try to be precise with our questioning and kind of get to the point.
We're going to talk a bit about how the recount expense process worked both
after the election and also how that's worked since the end of the Trump administration.
So, starting on that first question, take us to post-election day.
What's the process by which expenditures are approved by
Are you talking about any expenditure?
I mean, it's -- there's a lot of
To be specific, the recount expenses.
So what date -- where are we right now in time?
recount account and recount fund was used for a number of purposes.
make sure that I'm being responsive to your question.
actually -- I'm going to show you an exhibit that may help frame some of this, about what
It's an exhibit that will be up in a minute.
It's an email from you -- that comes to you from an individual named Stewart
And am I right that Mr. Crosland and Jones Day handled the campaign's
Can you tell us who that is?
Stewart Crosland is outside counsel at Jones Day.
So here's an email that's been marked exhibit 1.
9th email from Mr. Crosland from Jones Day, providing disclaimer language.
scroll to the bottom there, you see that Mr. Crosland --
It was how I had it laid out.
Is that -- maybe we can zoom in.
Is that better now for you?
So here you see it's a November 9th email from Mr. Crosland to you
and copying Sean Doi Iman, and it says:
This is what a split page would need.
It then has a disclaimer that would go at the bottom of a fund raising email.
It's very small on my screen.
It looks like it's from my production, so, yes.
And then you see, in the second paragraph there, it says:
contribution to DJTFP will be allocated to DJTFP's recount account up to the maximum of
Donations to DJTFP's recount account will be used solely in
connection with any post-election recounts and election contests and not for the purpose
Have you seen that disclaimer before?
So here it references a campaign recount account.
understand that recount account to be?
So I think I previously gave some testimony on this subject, but after election
day, when polls close, a campaign can raise money and make expenditures for two
The first is debt retirement, and the second one is recount.
And, as far as the latter, the recount option, did the campaign set up a
segregated account to handle those recount-related donations?
I believe so, but I -- I don't know all of the different accounts that the
campaign has, but I believe that they would've done that, yes.
And the campaign would've done that to be in compliance with
I don't know if it's required to be in compliance, but my guess is that that -- I
can't answer that question, whether or not there's a specific rule that requires it, sitting
And who would be the person at the campaign who would be tasked with
I mean, we would've taken advice from Jones Day.
would've been, you know, the treasury team and Sean Dallman.
And who would know from the campaign whether a segregated account
So your understanding was, as you just said, that when the funds -- after the
debt retirement, any funds the campaign itself was raising would've been for the purpose
of post-election recounts and otherwise challenging the election.
I mean, that is -- that is certainly one use of the funds.
Is there another use that you're aware of?
Well, I mean, I'll tell you that any expenditures that have been made out of
recount were made consistent with advice from outside counsel.
get into the substance of, you know, privileged conversations, but outside counsel did
provide advice with respect to what can and cannot be paid out of recount, and we
And I appreciate that, and we're not looking to get into your communication
with outside counsel, but we are looking to get a sense of your understanding as to what
these funds could and could not be used for.
Well, my understanding is that, like it says in the disclaimer here, it can't be
used -- one of the things it cannot be used for is to influence an election.
And is it fair to say --
And, consistent with this disclaimer that you received from outside counsel,
was it also your understanding that it could be used solely in connection with any
No, sir, that is not correct.
That is not consistent with the advice we got
So are you saying that the advice you got from outside counsel is not what is
in this disclaimer provided by outside counsel?
Well, I mean, I'm not -- I'm saying that there are categories here of
information -- look, this is the disclaimer that they provided to us.
advice from outside counsel about how we could use recount funds, and we used the
funds in accordance with that advice from outside counsel.
I'm not going to weigh in and provide advice on what's, you know, how I interpret
You guys can interpret the disclaimer.
Now, so, Mr. Cannon, I want to be clear.
Is it -- when you got this
disclaimer sent to you November 9th of 2020, it was your understanding that this
disclaimer would be what's going out to potential donors of the campaign, correct?
And when individuals made donations, post-election, to the campaign, they
were being told what their money would and would not be used for.
And when the disclaimer in the second paragraph says it would be used
solely in connection with any post-election recount and election contest, that was telling
donors what their money would be used solely for, is that fair, at that time?
I suppose -- I mean, I suppose so.
I think the language speaks for itself, and, you know, I
think it was -- I think that it was provided by the same counsel that provided the later
advice with respect to the use of the funds.
But if we scroll up here, Mr. Cannon, you forward this language on to Darren
I -- I mean, I can't see.
I'm saying -- asking, do you see that?
And then Mr. Centinello, who has a datapier address, then responds:
So you forward it to Mr. Centinello, right?
which disclaimer goes on the email?
So is it fair to say that when you forwarded this on to Mr. Centinello, you had
an understanding as to what that disclaimer meant, the import of it?
I knew it had to go at the bottom.
I knew, after election day, we
That's what Jones Day was telling us.
Can I ask a, I guess, a mechanical question?
make sense because it is very campaign-finance related.
disclaimers at the bottom of an email?
But how can you put two
I mean, are there two disclaimers at the bottom of any emails that you've
I'm trying to figure out what you mean when you say "both DJTFP and
Because he says, "which disclaimer goes on the emails, standard DJTFP,"
I'm not sure, sitting here right now, what I meant by that.
what I was getting at was that these are the disclaimers that are to be used on both DJTFP
But I mean, it's -- we're talking, I mean, this has been almost 2 years
I guess, if it was specific to that instance, I was
just curious if it meant the ones that included donations to both entities or if you actually
meant emails both from -- I was just trying to figure out what you meant there, what the
I probably could've answered that question 2 years ago.
All right, Mr. Cannon, I want to show you another email that we've marked
as exhibit 2, which is -- we talked about this email previously in your first transcribed
And I'm going to start with your -- on the second page of this email.
So it's 2 days later from the email we just discussed.
Cleta Mitchell, a lawyer with Foley Lardner at that time, sends you an email that says:
there a legal defense fund set up just for Trump campaign, or is that part of the JFC with
The campaign has a recount fund, and RNC has a
There is fundraising occurring through the JFA.
POTUS established a leadership PAC on Monday night that has been added to the JFA.
And that leadership PAC is Save America, correct?
If we scroll up further, Ms. Mitchell asks you questions about how
they can help, how she can help with money being raised.
We'll scroll up further, and then you provide some clarification, and you say:
There is no specific name for the recount fund.
held -- it says "help," but I think you meant held -- by the campaign.
Coates has to do with anything.
It's just a segregated, restricted account
So here -- does this refresh your recollection that you were aware that the
campaign had a segregated restricted account to which it raised recount funds?
It appears that at that time that was my understanding.
I mean, probably from someone on the treasury team.
And you would've gotten that understanding from who?
been, you know, either Sean, or it would've been Stewart Crosland, I mean, any number
Crosland was the attorney, or he was on the treasury team?
Stewart Crosland is the partner at Jones Day who worked under
Ben Ginsberg, who was providing outside counsel.
He could've told you about the fund that was created?
Well, yeah, because he would've been the one who advised the campaign
whether or not we had to have a restricted -- a segregated account or a non-segregated
Oh, I think we should be more particular.
I think my colleague was asking
who would've actually told you that the account had been set up.
I just want to -- we want to be very careful because there is this issue
with your counsel, and we don't want to ask you about communications with counsel.
So, understanding that counsel may have said you need to set up a fund, the
question of, but who would've told you that the fund had actually been created, it
sounded like that would've been more Mr. Doi Iman or somebody who would've actually
been responsible for setting up the fund.
I mean, they would've had to, in order to raise money into
I mean, it would've -- through the WinRed process and everything, it would have to
It would have to be aimed at an account.
And so I think that's what we were asking, is, you say it's a
segregated, restricted account, which presumably you may have gotten legal advice to
create, but who would've actually created such that money could go in, that would've
been Mr. Doi Iman or somebody on the actual treasury team.
Yeah, I don't know who else would've been
Now, Mr. Cannon, here in this email where you talk about the fundraising
through the joint fundraising agreement, you're talking about what's referred to as
There might've still been Trump Victory, but I don't think that we were doing
I think that was the only joint fund raising committee at that time.
small dollar fund raising through Trump Victory.
And that's my understanding as well from our investigation.
So is it then fair to say that the fundraising that's occurring around this time,
November 11th, that's going through TMAGAC, the funds that were being raised for the
purpose of campaign would've been going to this recount fund, this segregated account?
I don't know the split, though, because the RNC was a part of that, of
TMAGAC, the Trump campaign was a part of it, and I believe, at this time, Save America
was a part of it as well.
So, as of November 11th, I don't know what the split would've
Now, putting aside the split of how the money was actually -- the
percentages, but the RNC funds went to whatever the RNC had set up for themselves.
Save America went to whatever account Save America set up for itself, and the Trump
campaign funds would've gone to this segregated account that you reference here.
Again, there was a waterfall also that was occurring under the JFA at various
I don't know if as of November 11th, the waterfall had, you know, whether it was
a split or whether it was a waterfall within the debt retirement and recount, or whether it
was a waterfall with recount on top and debt retirement below.
I mean, I don't know as
For the purpose of our discussion, once the debt was paid off, as you noted
before, the campaign would've then been raising money for the purposes of recount
Once the debt was paid off -- I mean, I don't think debt was paid off until a
lot later because there's -- you know, there's trailing expenses, right?
debt was paid off as of a certain date.
I'm pretty sure there were trailing expenses.
There would've been -- there would've been an estimate, I presume, at some
point that was made of what the campaign's debt situation would be, and there would be
fundraising that would occur to meet whatever that estimate is.
Is it fair to say, which I believe you already testified to, that the funds
that did not go towards the debt, that the campaign fund raised post-election, would've
gone to this segregated or restricted account that you reference here?
It would have gone -- if it did not go -- so if it went to DJTFP prior to DJTFP's
conversion into a multi-candidate PAC, and it did not go into debt retirement, then it
probably the one who's the worst at this, so bear with me, apologies.
When you said the multi-candidate, that's MAGA PAC?
So, if I understand you, and I want to make sure -- if I repeat it, I
have a better chance of making sure I have it right.
So, if the funds were raised to DJTFP
and they were not spent on debt retirement, any remaining funds that were not spent on
debt retirement would have gone to this segregated, restricted account for recounts for
I just want to make sure I got it right.
I mean, that's my understanding of what should've -- what should've
happened, but, again, there was constant communication between our treasury team and
Jones Day throughout this entire period, so.
And we want to make sure it's your understanding, understanding that
you're not the person hitting these buttons and you may not actually know what
happened, just what your understanding of what the process was.
Just out of curiosity, and I know this was a while ago, but do you have a ball
park of how much money would've been moved to MAGA PAC after the debt was
retired -- after the debt was paid off, do you have any idea how much was then moved
into MAGA PAC, into the segregated, restricted account?
Well, no, I don't think there would've been money moved into a recount
Oh, then I misunderstood you a moment ago.
All that happens when a -- so, at the end of a campaign, the principal
It would've been raised into that account.
campaign committee can do one of two things.
can convert into a leadership PAC, or if it meets certain qualifications, it can revert into a
It can wind down and terminate, or it
The decision was made, with respect to this, predominantly because of a whole
host of, you know, legacy civil litigations, that we needed to convert into a
multi-candidate PAC because the FEC would not let us shut down the principal campaign
And so the money doesn't -- it would just sit and convert into MAGA
PAC, and it could only be used for recount.
debt was retired, do you have any idea how much money was left that could then only be
So I guess what I was asking was, after the
Well, I mean, I object a little bit with -- to the way you're leading me to say
that the money could only be used for recounts.
Oh, if that's not right, correct me, because if I'm getting it wrong, tell me.
I'm not going to -- I'm not going to get into privileged conversations, and
we've already agreed to that, but there is guidance from the FEC, there are advisory
opinions, that -- and specific guidance that was given to us by Jones Day, about what can
and cannot be spent out of a recount account.
Now, the recount account has that name.
It has that recount account name, but
there are other expenditures that can be made, provided they're not being used to
That is the advice that we got from outside counsel.
So I guess let me rephrase my question, and then you tell me if it's
Once the debt retirement was paid, so the debt was paid off, do you have
any idea how much money was left that DJTFP had that would then have to go
No, I don't know, but it would've been -- it would've been publicly reported.
I don't know if DJTFP would've had any additional money at that point.
I mean, it would -- it would all be contained in FEC reports.
So, if money changes accounts or is refunded to another account or
moved to another account, that's all publicly reported.
As well as staff at the FEC, I'd like to add too, so, you know, we have -- we've
been doing this, we've been filing reports now, MAGA PAC, Save America, have been
filing reports now for almost 2 years since election day.
We have yet to even receive a request for additional information from the FEC on
And that's a staff level, not talking about the Commissioners
upstairs, I'm talking about staff level at the FEC.
Was your question, are RFAls common, are requests for additional
I didn't mean to cut you off.
Do staff members commonly file RFAls?
You can get -- you can get an RFAI, request for additional information, you
can get those for something as simple as, you know, you used the word "consultant"
when they would prefer that you use the word "contractor."
So these are routine matters that happen at the FEC, and we have -- we've not
even received an RFAI, which is why it's sort of, like, you know, I'm a little perplexed as to
why this is something that this committee is looking into, just to be completely honest.
When was the last time -- you said you haven't received one.
it been since you received an RFAI?
Oh, I mean, I think it's been quite some time.
know, a question for -- those usually get sent to the treasurers, right, and then they get
forwarded to legal counsel for handling.
I just want to make clear who we're talking about.
the treasurer, are you talking about Red Curve, or are you talking about Mr. Doll man?
I'm talking about -- well, it would come through me to Mr. Doll man, but I
would assume that they're sent to -- I know that they're sent, actually, to Red Curve if
So, just in terms of understanding the process and making sure
we're using the correct terminology, when you say it would go to the treasurer, it would
go to Red Curve and then presumably to you and Mr. Doll man to respond?
Or to -- or to Jones Day to respond.
handled through either a letter back to the FEC explaining exactly what the report means,
or you do an amendment to a report.
I mean, I haven't -- I am aware that RFAls
It's not something that we've gotten a lot from, you know, this
particular committee, which is probably the most scrutinized political committee in the
Donald J. Trump for President, Inc.
There's multiples, so I just want to -- we try to
When you're saying "the committee," I just want to make sure which one
We were talking about a recount account, so I'm talking about
Donald J. Trump for President, Inc.
No, it's okay, you can confuse me with Mr. Dallman.
stronger and better looking than I am, so it's fine with me.
Mr. Cannon, we're going to have to head to a little later in November of
I'm going to show you what's been marked as exhibit 4.
So here -- so it's an email that you sent -- excuse me -- that Mr. Kushner sent you.
The initial email is, Sean Dallman actually sends a cash update, and he talks about:
Below the screenshot for the current position of the three accounts.
accounts, a DJTFP general is the first, recount/legal is the second, and Save America is the
Do you recall receiving these preaudit cash position updates?
I mean, I recall them because I gave a production to you guys, but I think I
testified previously that, if I hadn't done this production, I never would've recalled
receiving these, because I don't think I ever really paid a whole lot of attention to them.
I want to scroll up here, and here Mr. Kushner sent you an email.
I'm traveling for a few days -- it's November 29th -- he says:
discuss a new system for paying bills where we need DJT to sign off on them -- and that's
Mr. Trump, the President, right, DJT?
I want to create a tighter process for going forward.
have a budget we approve, and it shouldn't go to him unless approved by Sean and Justin
And that's talking about a budget going to approval by President Trump, correct?
That seems to be what Mr. Kushner's talking about, yes.
Did you have any other discussions about this so-called new system that
you know, a budget going forward or processes for approvals and things like that.
I mean, you know, I don't
I think I had previously testified that I don't recall having a conversation about,
Were you aware of President Trump's involvement in the approvals of
I don't believe this meeting ever happened.
What time period are we talking about, and what committee are we talking
Between -- from post-election through the end of the administration,
January 20th, are you aware of President Trump approving any kind of expenditures by
No, I'm not aware of that.
Going forward, when the campaign converts to MAGA PAC, is
President Trump involved in the process for approving expenses undertaken by MAGA
I don't believe I've ever had a conversation with him about expenses out of
MAGA PAC and whether or not certain things can get paid.
Well, broader than what conversations you've had, are you aware, from any
source, about whether President Trump has any involvement with MAGA PAC's
I mean, it would be -- it would be speculation on
my part, and I'm just not going to -- I'm not going to speculate on how expenses get
Do you know how MAGA PAC expenses get approved?
I mean, it -- well, wait a second.
know, are legal expenses that I'm aware of, right?
from receiving a bill to a wire going out or a check being cut, in granular detail, no, I don't
Because there's obviously some expenses that, you
Well, and I appreciate the clarification.
But in terms of what's the process
You just testified, as far as
President Trump's involvement from the election day to January 20th, you don't have any
knowledge as to whether or not he was involved in the approval of expenses.
Now, going after January 20th, and I believe in February when MAGA PAC
emerges as an entity, are you aware of whether President Trump has any involvement in
the approval of MAGA PAC's expenses, in any way?
I -- I just -- it's -- I don't know.
It's okay to say you don't know, Mr. Cannon.
what we're trying to find out, is, who are the people that have the information about the
process, because our understanding is, is that a lot of people left, a lot of people don't
It's who was at MAGA PAC or who was running these things or what happened
after the transition, that's what we're trying to find out.
person who doesn't know, that's fine.
So, if you're not the proper
If you know who a better person is, who handles the mechanics of that stuff, and
say, "Oh, actually I'm not the person, this would be the person," that would be super
So, if you don't know, we don't want to ask the wrong people the information.
But if you do know who the proper person is, we understand people change, just that
would be helpful too, so that's fine.
Do you know who is tasked with the approving expenses for MAGA PAC?
Yeah, I mean, I believe -- so when you say "approving expenses," this is one I
really want to make sure we're on the same page, okay, because we may receive, you
know, a bill, from a law firm that's representing us in, you know, some civil litigation.
I'll take a look at that because a lot of times I end up working with these people,
So I'll take a look at that and say:
Generally I respond with "this looks good to me" or "hang on, I'm going to call this
outside counsel and figure out what the deal is with the bill."
After that, I don't know the process.
My last step in the process is sending an email to somebody who's on the
What's your last step in the process?
accounts payable group -- it could be Mr. Dallman; it could be Kalina (ph) -- and saying:
Hey, this bill looks good to me.
So is there anyone -- to the extent there's a hierarchy, is there anyone more
senior than you that you would confer with or otherwise get approval from before saying
yes to someone like Mr. Doll man or Kalina (ph)?
No, there's no one that I would go higher to.
They'd go -- would go up to
And Ms. Wiles works for MAGA PAC?
I mean, she's -- she -- I don't know exactly what her employment
And I'll note for the -- sorry, I'll note for the record that
Mr. Aguilar has joined the Webex.
Mr. Cannon, feel free to continue your answer.
So I was saying I think that ultimately I don't know whether the
former President approves expenses, whether Susie Wiles approves expenses, or whether
it's some combination of the two.
So an expense comes -- and do all expenses typically come to you first, or is
Only things that relate to legal.
So a legal expense comes from you; you may do some due diligence
to see it's right on your end.
You then send that -- you then give an approval for
payment to someone like Mr. Doi Iman or Kalina (ph), and then they, for lack of a better
term, go up the chain to get additional approval separate from you?
And who do you understand to be up the chain from Mr. Dallman?
Well, I thought I just answered that.
Is it just -- is it Susie Wiles and then President Trump?
I -- I mean, I think it's -- again, I don't know what happens after Sean.
believe that there's a report that gets sent to Susie.
I don't know what the approval
Hey, this legal expense looks good.
Mr. Cannon, do you know the relationship between Mr. Doi Iman and
Ms. Wiles, whether she's above him, whether -- how that process works?
I think she's -- she's effectively everyone's supervisor.
And when you say "everyone," understanding that you don't know
exactly who her employer may be or who actually pays her salary, when you say she's
supervising everyone, is it your understanding that she's supervising everyone at MAGA
I mean, everyone at MAGA -- I don't know how to -- I don't -- it's not
like -- this isn't like corporate America, you know.
much more satisfying if it was, but it's -- you know, it's a -- it's a leadership PAC, and
people provide certain services to this PAC, provide certain services to other PACs,
But if you can explain, like, when you say it's not
like corporate America, in what sense?
There's people -- there's people that volunteer their time.
In the sense that, well, they don't all have one
They could be doing the job -- like, can you unpack that for me because it's
I know that that's -- it would be so
There's people that are W-2 employees.
So, if I'm understanding you, I'm oversimplifying it when I say, quote, they're
working for MAGA because that makes it sound like one entity is employing all of them,
but it could be that they're collectively doing work for MAGA and paid by all -- by
different organizations or structured differently and possibly not even be employees.
Yeah, I think -- I mean, for some -- some people might be employees.
people might have their own consulting businesses.
they're charging what clients, what they're doing.
So is it more accurate for me to say the work that they're doing for MAGA
PAC that Ms. Wiles is reviewing in some capacity?
I mean, I think you're asking Mr. Cannon
I don't know what the point of that is.
I'm asking Mr. Cannon to clarify because he clearly has expertise in
this area, and in our attempts to be clear -- and what I don't want to do is to accidentally
misstate something, to Mr. Cannon's point, if my experience in corporate America is
making it so that I'm not asking the question properly.
His explanation and clarification is very helpful.
knowledge and expertise, a very helpful explanation that then prevents me from
My understanding was, it was an explanation based on knowledge and expertise.
I didn't see it as speculation.
You know, whatever you think is helpful is fine, but,
you know, it's calling -- asking him to speculate who approves what, where, when
probably doesn't make a lot of sense.
No, I'm just asking for his understanding of the process.
-- I want to remind you that we have a hard stop at 3 o'clock, so.
And I just want to remind you that --
I just want to -- we wanted his understanding of the
process, and I think he's provided that.
Mr. Cannon, let's move forward to the formation of MAGA PAC in
Were you involved in that process, the formation or conversion of
I would've been aware of it, yeah.
Who was, you know -- if you were aware, who was
the person who was actually handling the actual nitty-gritty of that work?
I don't know how nitty-gritty it is.
I think it's just filing a form with the FEC.
